channel.title: News on Jakarta EE: The New Home of Cloud Native Java
channel.description: Recent content in News on Jakarta EE: The New Home of Cloud Native Java

item.title: Understanding Jakarta EE: “Jakarta EE should become more modular than it is right now”
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Confused about what’s going on with Jakarta EE? This interview series is meant to help you navigate through all the changes and understand where it’s headed, as well as how Jakarta EE plans to become the new home of cloud-native Java. Our fourth guest is Werner Keil. Let’s dive deeper into the Jakarta EE universe!

item.title: Eclipse Foundation Announces Jakarta EE Committee Election Results
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Ottawa, Canada - July 31, 2018 - Today we are pleased to announce the results of the Participant and Committer Member elections for representatives to the Jakarta EE Working Group Steering Committee, Specification Committee, and Marketing & Brand Committee. These committees provide governance for the evolution and adoption of Jakarta EE, the community-led platform created from the contribution of Java EE technologies and hosted by the Eclipse Foundation.

item.title: Thoughts On Jakarta EE’s Vision
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Jakarta EE is currently being formed under the Eclipse Foundation. In order to align the future development, directions, and marketing to the industry, many claim that it’s crucial for the Jakarta EE community to share a common vision or mission statement that the technology will follow.

item.title: Understanding Jakarta EE: “The platform needs to evolve more dynamically than it had done in the past”
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Confused about what’s going on with Jakarta EE? This interview series is meant to help you navigate through all the changes and understand where it’s headed, as well as how Jakarta EE plans to become the new home of cloud-native Java. Our third guest is Java Champion Josh Juneau. Let’s dive deeper into the Jakarta EE universe!

item.title: Understanding Jakarta EE: “I strongly believe there is a lot to do to make Jakarta EE ready for the future”
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Confused about what’s going on with Jakarta EE? This interview series is meant to help you navigate through all the changes and understand where it’s headed, as well as how Jakarta EE plans to become the new home of cloud-native Java. Our second guest is Markus Eisele, Java Champion and Head of Developer Advocacy at Lightbend. Let’s dive deeper into the Jakarta EE universe!

item.title: Jakarta EE: No turning back
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Jakarta EE is forging a new path forwards for enterprise Java. In this opinion piece, Cesar Saavedra explains why Jakarta EE is a breath of fresh air for enterprise Java.

item.title: Jakarta EE, Eclipse MicroProfile and Cloud-Native at EclipseCon France
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: These are exciting times for the Java community! EclipseCon France (ECF) 2018, the first ECF since Oracle contributed Java EE to Eclipse Foundation, surely reflected that.

item.title: Jakarta EE Marketing and Social Media Update
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: An update on our marketing efforts to promote awareness, contributions, adoption, and support of Jakarta EE.

item.title: Testing JavaEE backward and forward compatibility with Servlet, JAX-RS, Batch and Microprofile
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: One of the most interesting concepts that made Java EE (and Java) appealing for the enterprise is its great backward compatibility, ensuring that years of investment in R&D could be reused in future developments.

item.title: 2018 Java Ecosystem Executive Insights
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Take a look at what more than a dozen executives have to say about the Java ecosystem and what’s on the horizon.

item.title: Proposed Jakarta EE Design Principles
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Let’s take a look at some suggested design principles that some feel Jakarta EE should follow. What suggestions do you have?

item.title: Lightbend Podcast: Why Lightbend Joined The Eclipse Foundation’s Jakarta EE Working Group (9 Min)
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: In this Lightbend Podcast, we sit down with our CEO, Mark Brewer, to discuss what joining the Eclipse Foundation as a founding member of the Jakarta EE Working Group means for bringing Reactive closer to the traditional Java enterprise landscape.

item.title: Enter Jakarta EE: an Inoculation Against Fear, Uncertainty and Doubt in the Java Community
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Why I stopped worrying and learned to love changes in governance and branding.

item.title: Enterprise Java in the Blogosphere
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: So much has happened in the enterprise Java space over the past few months that it kind of boggles the mind.

item.title: ​Where does Java in the enterprise go from here?
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Oracle recently freed J2EE, aka Java EE. Now known as Jakarta EE, enterprise Java’s new manager the Eclipse Foundation is revealing its plans for the popular middleware platform.

item.title: Jakarta EE Newsletter - A First Look
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: The first issue of the Jakarta EE quarterly newsletter has been published. Read it now!

item.title: Jakarta EE Progress to Date
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Last September Oracle announced, with the support of IBM and Red Hat, that Java EE was going to move to the Eclipse Foundation.

item.title: Jakarta EE at EclipseCon France 2018
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Meet the community at the Unconference and take in the talks on Jakarta EE, MicroServices, Microprofile and EE4J, June 11-13 in Toulouse.

item.title: Proprietary to Open: A Sea Change for Jakarta EE
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Although a big part of this is the brand change from Java EE to Jakarta EE as well as a new technical direction (i.e. cloud-native and microservices) the most important change will be the move from a proprietary Java EE to fully open source Jakarta EE platform.

item.title: Latest Roundup of EE4J Activities for Jakarta EE
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: There has been a recent flurry of EE4J activity as the Eclipse Foundation is positioning Jakarta EE as the new home for cloud native Java.

item.title: Java roadmap: Eclipse’s Jakarta EE enterprise Java takes shape
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: The Eclipse Foundation outlines the 39 projects that will make up the new cloud-native, microservices-friendly enterprise Java effort, and how GlassFish will evolve.

item.title: Goodbye, Java Enterprise Edition. Hello, Jakarta EE
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Developers who use Java Enterprise Edition will be happy to know that the development and runtime platform is gaining new life as Jakarta EE. As part of an agreement with Oracle, the tech giant will give up control over the platform to Eclipse Foundation, which has big plans to remake enterprise Java for the emerging cloud world.

item.title: Background on Oracle’s contribution to Jakarta EE
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: We are on our way to making the contribution we proposed last September a reality!

item.title: The road to Jakarta EE
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Jakarta EE launch is a good occasion to reflect on how we got here…

item.title: The Eclipse Foundation has established Jakarta EE Working Group
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Fujitsu is now a Strategic Member of Eclipse Foundation and will be an active member of the Eclipse Board of Directors and Jakarta EE.

item.title: Eclipse Foundation Unveils New Cloud Native Java Future with Jakarta EE
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Future evolution of Java EE, Jakarta EE stack moves to the Eclipse Foundation.

item.title: In Support of Jakarta EE’s Quest to Accelerate Cloud Native Java
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: The right environment is now in place to reinvigorate Java’s most popular run-time platform with an open source-first approach and a commitment to truly putting the community into Jakarta EE.

item.title: Jakarta EE - the new home for enterprise Java
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Official Moving Day! New Open Community Stewardship and Governance Model now with Eclipse Foundation.

item.title: Jakarta EE Community Survey of 1,800+ Java Developers Reveals “Cloud Native” Top Requirement in Platform’s Evolution
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: The Eclipse Foundation conducts largest survey to date of Java community on key priorities for future releases of Jakarta EE.

item.title: Jakarta EE is Officially Out!
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Jakarta EE is officially out! With Jakarta EE all of us involved in working towards the release hope that we can use it as a catalyst to bring together communities under a single banner.

item.title: The Future of Cloud Native Open Source Java with Jakarta EE
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: It’s here! The Eclipse Foundation has announced the future of Java EE with the release of Jakarta EE: a cloud-native Java and an open source governance model.
